urn:contentItem:5WXS-YKY1-DYWP-R3VJ-00000-00Amazon to offer help for customers who search about suicide2019-08-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESSAmazon to offer help for customers who search about suicide

REUTERS: Amazon.com Inc plans to promote helpline phone numbers to customers who query its site about suicide, the company told Reuters on Thursday, after searches on its site suggested users search for nooses and other potentially harmful products. Searching for the word "suicide" last week on Amazon's U.S. marketplace resulted in the webpage showing users to "suicide kits" and nooses. Results from its India website included sleeping pills, pesticides and a book entitled "How To Commit Suicide."

Regulatory scrutiny of big tech companies is increasing with Amazon facing challenges in policing its sprawling marketplace, where merchants can massage the listings of banned or illegal goods so they go undetected. Amazon took down listings for the book and rope nooses after learning of them. The company prohibits merchants from selling non-media products that promote or glorify suicide, according to its website. A Wall Street Journal report last week also identified more than 4,000 items on Amazon that were deceptively labelled or that U.S. agencies had banned or deemed dangerous. Alphabet Inc's Google , Facebook Inc and Twitter Inc have already been issuing helpline numbers in response to user queries involving the term "suicide." While social media platforms have been scrutinized in recent months about how they moderate violent and potentially dangerous content, so far the debate has touched little on the world's top online retailer. Amazon said it encouraged customers who had concerns about an item to click the feedback box, located at the bottom of an item's detail page. The suicide helpline information will be added to detail pages of certain products, informing customers that free and confidential support is available through organizations such as the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. The message will be rolled out in the coming weeks for customers searching phrases related to suicide and will appear on relevant book product detail pages in the United States and United Kingdom from next week. (Reporting by Munsif Vengattil in Bengaluru and Jeffrey Dastin in San Francisco; Editing by Patrick Graham and Lisa Shumaker) - Reuters

urn:contentItem:5WW4-PKV1-DYFF-80KW-00000-00Amazon tries to court critics through tours2019-08-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:05ZLexisNexisAPg. 006Amazon tries to court critics through toursJay Greene Washington Post

WASHINGTON - From the White House to the campaign trail for the Democratic presidential nomination, politicians have found a popular punching bag in Amazon, accusing the retail giant of paying subsistence wages to warehouse workers while dodging taxes.

That's one reason why Amazon has aggressively courted members of Congress to walk the floors of its vast warehouses, afterward noting those visits on its social media accounts. On Aug. 15, for example, when the Twitter account for the company's policy arm retweeted a post from Sen. Marsha Blackburn, R-Tenn., noting her "great" tour of Amazon's warehouse in Chattanooga, Tennessee.

Blackburn has been a critic of big tech and chairs the new Senate Judiciary Committee's tech task force, which is looking at privacy, data security, censorship and antitrust. Her spokeswoman did not respond to a request for comment.

For years, Amazon's critics have chided the company for underpaying and overworking warehouse employees. In the U.S., it employs about 250,000 typically hourly workers, many who perform strenuous and repetitive jobs like walking many miles a day, picking items off shelves or packing up boxes. In response, the online retail giant has launched a campaign to try to turn the tide as regulators take a closer look at the company for potential abuses of its power.

The efforts, though, haven't seemed to tone down the political rhetoric aimed at the online retail giant.

(Amazon founder and chief executive Jeff Bezos owns the Washington Post.)

The company unleashed a squad of warehouse workers, so-called "FC Ambassadors," on Twitter roughly a year ago to refute the narrative of harsh working conditions. Some of the tweets have been ridiculed on social media.

Amazon also caught heat last year after a move to raise its minimum wage to $15 an hour included plans to take away some bonuses and stock grants for warehouse workers.

That move came shortly after Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., introduced the Stop Bad Employers by Zeroing Out Subsidies Act, or Stop BEZOS Act, that would require large employers such as Amazon to pay the government for food stamps, public housing, Medicaid and other federal assistance received by their workers. The bill currently sits in the Senate Finance Committee.

Amazon has stepped up efforts to push back against its critics, including offering tours at 23 warehouses in the United States to let visitors see first-hand how its facilities operate.

The spate of warehouse visits hasn't toned down any of the opprobrium from Amazon's fiercest critics. Sanders had said he would visit an Amazon fulfillment center. But in his ongoing sparring with the company, he has said he's "not interested in a photo op at an Amazon warehouse."

urn:contentItem:5MG2-XDK1-DYRG-W12X-00000-00Amazon tries to deliver soulless automation;Amazon striving to deliver soulless automation2016-12-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:05ZLexisNexisDatebookPg. E8CAILLE MILLNERAmazon tries to deliver soulless automationAmazon striving to deliver soulless automationBy Caille Millner

I recently watched the grimmest Christmas story I've seen in a long time. It was Amazon video of its first drone delivery.

For the past several years, Amazon has been trying to deliver packages via drones. On Dec. 7, the company announced it had officially launched its program, known as Prime Air, in Cambridge, England.

In a short video posted to its website, the company showed the track the drone used to launch, the drone's strenuous plod across a field, and the customer - a rotund, bespectacled man who had presumably decided it was too much trouble to go to the supermarket for a bag of sweet-and-salty popcorn.

The video announcer explained the proceedings with an air of earnest wonder, and a stamp on the footage helpfully added that we were watching "actual flight footage not simulated."

In the mind of some marketing person, I'm sure the stamp was meant to impress viewers. But because the words are in all uppercase and framed by a stark white border, it looks like a threat.

Like a lot of Big Tech, Amazon doesn't seem to understand why anyone would eye its brave endeavors in innovation with skepticism.

The drone program faced years of public concern and regulatory hurdles; one of the reasons the launch took place in Britain was that the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration is - for now, at least - determined to maintain certain restrictions on the flight patterns and piloting of delivery drones.

Here's a shocker: Amazon is impatient with the FAA's hesitation. "Amazon believes the current model of airspace management will not meet future ... demands, particularly highly-automated, low-altitude commercial operations," the company wrote in a July 2015 airspace proposal. It said that "a paradigm shift in airspace management and operations is necessary."

Missing from all of this Brave New World discussion is the question of whether any of this is necessary.

Oh, I know it's necessary for Amazon - the company hates depending on shipping companies, like UPS and the U.S. Postal Service, for its world-domination plans. Amazon needs drones because drones are crucial to consolidating its future control of the supply chain. The company doesn't register as a matter of particular interest the fact that the shipping supply chain is one of the few remaining industries where blue-collar Americans can still make an adequate living.

But if the last year of backlash elections around the world has made anything clear, it's the fact that there are plenty of citizens who do consider making an adequate living to be a matter of particular interest. In fact, they'd much rather have jobs than watch robots deliver bags of popcorn to their homes in 13 minutes, and they're desperate enough to vote for any snake-oil scheme that promises them the former instead of the latter.

When the pitchforks start showing up and they're not far away, I hope Big Tech rues spending so many years chasing "innovations" that decimated employment in exchange for the tiniest of gains in productivity, utility and human happiness.

Human happiness - yes, that warm, fuzzy, squishy beast was on my mind as I was watching the drone video.

Why, I asked myself, do I feel happier thinking about getting a delivery from a human being in a snazzy uniform, huge ring of keys rattling at her hip, than I feel about getting a delivery from a small, silent robot?

Could it be, readers, that there are reasons for shopping that go beyond the exchange of money for a physical good?

If you've ever had a pleasant interaction in a physical store with another customer or an employee, you already know the answer to this question.

If you've ever had a UPS driver or a Postal Service employee ask you how your day was going, you already know the answer to this question.

Outside of Amazon's shareholders, no one wants to live in a world where we are left alone with nothing but our packages.

The realization that we are a step closer to that reality upset me so much, I couldn't watch the delivery video all the way to the end. I hit pause at 1:53, stood up and stepped outside.

A brown UPS truck was parked across the street. I watched the driver step down from his seat, holding an armload of packages. Despite his burden, he lifted one hand to wave hello to me. I waved back at him. I kept waving, even after he'd entered the building across the street and could no longer see me.

"I hope Big Tech rues spending so many years chasing innovations that decimated employment in exchange for the tiniest of gains. "

urn:contentItem:5FF0-1HF1-JB5Y-N537-00000-00Amazon Tries To Make Up For Lost Lobby Time With Jay Carney2015-03-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:06ZLexisNexisAmazon Tries To Make Up For Lost Lobby Time With Jay Carney

Mar 02, 2015( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex) Amazon just became one of the top ten retailers in the United States[1], it has laid waste to book stores and it's looking to expand its brick-and-mortar presence while trying to deliver packages with its own fleet of drones. But that frenetic growth and ambition hasn't converted into Washington influence, something the company hopes to remedy with last week's hiring of former White House Press Secretary Jay Carney. Other technology heavyweights, from Google and Microsoft to Apple, have already boosted political spending as their ambition extends well beyond laptops and search results.

Big tech's big hope is that high-priced D.C. insiders like Carney can cut through regulatory hurdles that threaten to derail a host of ambitious plans. Taking on Carney, who served as President Obama's spokesman from 2011 to 2014, puts Amazon just a call away from the most powerful lawmakers in the country. It's a sea-change for a company that's remained mostly quiet in Washington even as rivals have jumped into the lobbying frenzy. But Carney[2]'s hiring also puts an exclamation point on the idea that, if the cool kids in Silicon Valley really want to take over the world, first they need to make nice with Washington power brokers. Unlike Facebook, Google, Microsoft and other giants that have spent the last few years building up their public policy departments Amazon has mostly tried to go it alone, and without much success. Google has spent more on lobbying[3] than any other corporation since 2012. Part of the reason for that is the company's plan to develop driverless cars, which were forbidden on many California streets. Now, after a campaign that included giving politicians test rides and suggesting driverless cars as a remedy for drunk driving, Google won 25 permits[4] to test autonomous vehicles. There have also been reports that Google is developing its own drone program, a possible foray into the delivery strategy Amazon is eyeing. Facebook, led by founder Mark Zuckerberg, has become an increasingly vocal part of the debate over immigration reform. More than 15-percent of the company's workers hold H-1B visas, which permit foreign workers to live inside the U.S. temporarily if they work in a specialist occupation. Other Facebook priorities include[5] protecting freedom of expression online, Internet security education, privacy legislation and online advertising laws. Playing Catch Up Amazon has been less conspicuous, and consistent, when it comes to public policy. First the company appeared indecisive on its support for the Marketplace Fairness Act[6], a bill that died in Congress before it would have forced e-commerce companies to collect sales tax from customers in each state where their products are sold. Amazon initially opposed the bill, pulling an about-face upon the realization that, with brick-and-mortar warehouses in states throughout the U.S., it would be on the hook to collect taxes anyway. Amazon decided it might as well advocate competitors like eBay being forced to pay taxes, too. Then the Federal Aviation Administration issued new rules that grounded the plan[7] to deliver packages by drone. More than a year after Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos announced the company hopes to cut out the middle man and deliver its own packages, the FAA adopted regulations forcing drone pilots to operate their aircraft only within their line of sight. Now, as Amazon expands into everything from bigger delivery plans to movie production, it's certain to run into resistance from more than just technology rivals. 'Business doesn't like to be regulated but it loves to hire politicians,' said Julian Zelizer, a professor of history and public affairs at Princeton University. 'Amazon has a number of public policy issues they have to deal with and they're looking for people who can get them into a room to meet with powerful officials. They want someone who has a feel for Washington, and companies realize there's no one better for that than the people who have actually been there.' Today's tech giants are investing heavily outside their own roots in part because computers and software can now be found in virtually all consumer products - from toasters to automobiles. That makes almost everything a potential tech product. So it makes sense that, as lawmakers attempt to determine, say, how driverless cars will operate and whether delivery drones are legal, the companies that stand to profit off such ventures will want to influence policy from the inside. Amazon has known for years that it wants to do more than push Barnes and Noble[8] out of business. Between 2003 to 2014 it increased its lobby spending from $920,000 to $4.9 million, according to OpenSecrets.org[9]. Google has also known it wants to be more than a search engine, and has increased its schmooze spending from $80,000 to $16.83 million over the same period. Ongoing Turf Wars That's partly because Google has been locked in an ugly feud with Microsoft (which spent $10.49 million on lobbying[10] in 2013) for years. They've fought over virtually every major technology issue over the past decade, everything from search results, patents, privacy policies and security measures. What both companies have in common, though, is that the people on the front lines of their ongoing war gained experience in the trenches of Washington politics. The arms race has almost certainly contributed to Microsoft's hire of Mark Penn, a former spin doctor for Hillary Clinton who now serves as chief strategy officer under CEO Satya Nadella. That came not long after Google brought on Susan Molinari, a former member of the U.S. House of Representatives, to work as a vice president for public policy. Sheryl Sandberg, meanwhile, worked at the U.S. Treasury Department before serving as Facebook's chief operating officer. Uber, in its quest to become more than a taxi service, caught on earlier this year by hiring Obama's highly visible campaign manager, David Plouffe, to improve its corporate image. Since then Uber has refuted the claim that its drivers don't earn a fair salary[11] and released a later disputed report[12] that Uber's presence in an area reduces the number of drunk drivers. 'The technology sector is becoming very entrenched with government policy,' Zelizer said. 'It's not just a booming industry but one that has been consciously removed from politics and is now trying to strengthen its presence in Washington.' urn:contentItem:5FDW-B6F1-JCMN-Y2B6-00000-00Amazon Tries To Make Up For Lost Lobby Time With Jay Carney2015-03-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:06ZLexisNexisAmazon Tries To Make Up For Lost Lobby Time With Jay CarneyJeff Stone

Mar 02, 2015( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Amazon just became one of the top ten retailers in the United States[1], it has laid waste to book stores and it's looking to expand its brick-and-mortar presence while trying to deliver packages with its own fleet of drones. But that frenetic growth and ambition hasn't converted into Washington influence, something the company hopes to remedy with last week's hiring of former White House Press Secretary Jay Carney. Other technology heavyweights, from Google and Microsoftto Apple, have already boosted political spending as their ambition extends well beyond laptops and search results.<nl/>

Big tech's big hope is that high-priced D.C. insiders like Carney can cut through regulatory hurdles that threaten to derail a host of ambitious plans.<nl/> Taking on Carney, who served as President Obama's spokesman from 2011 to 2014, puts Amazon just a call away from the most powerful lawmakers in the country. It's a sea-change for a company that's remained mostly quiet in Washington even as rivals have jumped into the lobbying frenzy. But Carney[2]'s hiring also puts an exclamation point on the idea that, if the cool kids in Silicon Valley really want to take over the world, first they need to make nice with Washington power brokers.<nl/> Unlike Facebook, Google, Microsoft and other giants that have spent the last few years building up their public policy departments Amazon has mostly tried to go it alone, and without much success.<nl/> Googlehas spent more on lobbying[3] than any other corporation since 2012. Part of the reason for that is the company's plan to develop driverless cars, which were forbidden on many California streets. Now, after a campaign that included giving politicians test rides and suggesting driverless cars as a remedy for drunk driving, Googlewon 25 permits[4] to test autonomous vehicles.<nl/> There have also been reports that Googleis developing its own drone program, a possible foray into the delivery strategy Amazon is eyeing.<nl/> Facebook, led by founder Mark Zuckerberg, has become an increasingly vocal part of the debate over immigration reform. More than 15-percent of the company's workers hold H-1B visas, which permit foreign workers to live inside the U.S. temporarily if they work in a specialist occupation. Other Facebook priorities include[5] protecting freedom of expression online, Internet security education, privacy legislation and online advertising laws.<nl/> Playing Catch Up<nl/> Amazon has been less conspicuous, and consistent, when it comes to public policy.<nl/> First the company appeared indecisive on its support for the Marketplace Fairness Act[6], a bill that died in Congress before it would have forced e-commerce companies to collect sales tax from customers in each state where their products are sold. Amazon initially opposed the bill, pulling an about-face upon the realization that, with brick-and-mortar warehouses in states throughout the U.S., it would be on the hook to collect taxes anyway. Amazon decided it might as well advocate competitors like eBay being forced to pay taxes, too.<nl/> Then the Federal Aviation Administration issued new rules that grounded the plan[7] to deliver packages by drone. More than a year after Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos announced the company hopes to cut out the middle man and deliver its own packages, the FAA adopted regulations forcing drone pilots to operate their aircraft only within their line of sight.<nl/> Now, as Amazon expands into everything from bigger delivery plans to movie production, it's certain to run into resistance from more than just technology rivals.<nl/> 'Business doesn't like to be regulated but it loves to hire politicians,' said Julian Zelizer, a professor of history and public affairs at Princeton University. 'Amazon has a number of public policy issues they have to deal with and they're looking for people who can get them into a room to meet with powerful officials. They want someone who has a feel for Washington, and companies realize there's no one better for that than the people who have actually been there.'<nl/> Today's tech giants are investing heavily outside their own roots in part because computers and software can now be found in virtually all consumer products - from toasters to automobiles. That makes almost everything a potential tech product. So it makes sense that, as lawmakers attempt to determine, say, how driverless cars will operate and whether delivery drones are legal, the companies that stand to profit off such ventures will want to influence policy from the inside.<nl/> Amazon has known for years that it wants to do more than push Barnes and Noble[8] out of business. Between 2003 to 2014 it increased its lobby spending from $920,000 to $4.9 million, according to OpenSecrets.org[9]. Googlehas also known it wants to be more than a search engine, and has increased its schmooze spending from $80,000 to $16.83 million over the same period.<nl/> Ongoing Turf Wars<nl/> That's partly because Googlehas been locked in an ugly feud with Microsoft (which spent $10.49 million on lobbying[10] in 2013) for years. They've fought over virtually every major technology issue over the past decade, everything from search results, patents, privacy policies and security measures. What both companies have in common, though, is that the people on the front lines of their ongoing war gained experience in the trenches of Washington politics.<nl/> The arms race has almost certainly contributed to Microsoft's hire of Mark Penn, a former spin doctor for Hillary Clinton who now serves as chief strategy officer under CEO Satya Nadella. That came not long after Googlebrought on Susan Molinari, a former member of the U.S. House of Representatives, to work as a vice president for public policy. Sheryl Sandberg, meanwhile, worked at the U.S. Treasury Department before serving as Facebook's chief operating officer.<nl/> Uber, in its quest to become more than a taxi service, caught on earlier this year by hiring Obama's highly visible campaign manager, David Plouffe, to improve its corporate image. Since then Uber has refuted the claim that its drivers don't earn a fair salary[11] and released a later disputed report[12] that Uber's presence in an area reduces the number of drunk drivers.<nl/> 'The technology sector is becoming very entrenched with government policy,' Zelizer said. 'It's not just a booming industry but one that has been consciously removed from politics and is now trying to strengthen its presence in Washington.'<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.ibtimes.com/top-10-us-retailers-amazon-joins-ranks-walmart-kroger-first-time-ever-1618774 [ 2]:   http://www.ibtimes.com/jay-carneys-amazon-do-list-drones-internet-sales-tax-eurocrats-1829764 [ 3]:   http://pando.com/2014/11/13/google-is-the-biggest-corporate-lobbyist-in-america-now-says-new-public-citizen-report/ [ 4]:   http://www.theverge.com/2014/9/22/6828161/california-permits-self-driving-cars-google-audi-mercedes-benz [ 5]:   http://techcrunch.com/2013/01/23/google-facebook-lobbying-spend/ [ 6]:   http://www.ibtimes.com/bill-kill-internet-sales-tax-demise-hurts-big-box-chains-so-why-isnt-amazon-smiling-1723343 [ 7]:   http://www.ibtimes.com/amazon-committed-prime-air-drone-delivery-will-contest-faa-restrictions-1818086 [ 8]:   http://qz.com/352574/barnes-nobles-college-bookstores-division-can-run-but-it-cant-hide-from-amazon/ [ 9]:   https://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientsum.php?id=D000023883 [ 10]:   https://www.opensecrets.org/orgs/summary.php?id=D000000115...le=2014 [ 11]:   http://blog.uber.com/partner-experience [ 12]:   http://www.propublica.org/article/uber-claims-credit-for-drop-in-drunk-driving-accidents-but-wheres-evidence

urn:contentItem:5PR7-VYM1-JC85-N43D-00000-00Amazon Turns on the Charm Amid Criticism From Right and Left2017-10-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:05ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYAmazon Turns on the Charm Amid Criticism From Right and LeftCECILIA KANGWASHINGTONABSTRACT

After years of relying on a no-frills lobbying operation, Amazon is spreading its message far and wide in the nation's capital.

FULL TEXT

WASHINGTON - On a sunny day in July, commuters arriving at Union Station, in the shadow of Capitol Hill, were greeted with free bananas passed out by Amazon employees. In a Senate building, lawmakers and their aides attended policy panels on how Amazon manages privacy on its Echo devices and how sales for small businesses are booming on its online store.

The day was capped off with a cocktail reception hosted by Amazon's chief spokesman, Jay Carney - the former press secretary to President Obama.

The public relations and lobbying push represents a new face for Amazon in Washington. Facing greater skepticism about its growing power over retail, including from President Trump, Amazon is following the well-worn path of oil, pharmaceutical and even other large tech companies, which try to bend policy in their favor by enhancing connections with federal officials.

Amazon is sweeping the nation's capitol with a branding campaign of jobs creation and support for small businesses, promoting the upsides of its major expansion in media, groceries and transportation. This year, Amazon has increased its lobbying staff to 83 members from 60, making it one of the biggest corporate lobbying shops in town. The company is also on its way to surpassing its previous high for lobbying spending: $11.3 million last year. The $6.2 million Amazon spent in the first two quarters of this year was the 11th most among companies, above Exxon and far above Walmart, which spent $3.6 million in the same period.

The company's more aggressive approach, focused on building relationships with leading politicians and improving the company's overall reputation, is a break from its past. Before last year, the company relied on a no-frills operation for more than a decade, prodding officials in Washington on narrow laws and regulations and arguing about the nuances of issues like sales taxes and copyright.

The efforts may not directly apply to an imminent bill or regulation, but they allow the company to steer policy conversations that may be important to Amazon in the future. Amazon is hosting events for lawmakers, like the day of events in July, and holding discussions on transportation and labor policies for congressional staff and policy makers at its sleek offices near Capitol Hill. Speaker Paul D. Ryan and other political leaders have visited Amazon's fulfillment centers in their home districts, where Amazon talks up the thousands of jobs those warehouses support.

Amazon's strategic shift has happened as politicians are getting bolder in their criticism about the size and influence of big tech companies. Republicans and Democrats alike have focused on issues including antitrust, privacy and public disclosure.

Many of the harshest attacks have been directed at Facebook and Google, which also have robust lobbying arms in Washington. But Amazon has attracted its own set of vocal critics, who say the company's push into groceries, fashion, transportation and other industries threatens competition. President Trump has lashed out at the company and Jeff Bezos, the company's chief executive, multiple times, accusing the company of avoiding taxes among other things. The company has said it follows all tax laws and has supported a bill that would force online commerce sites to collect sales taxes.

"The concentration of power in the hands of a few companies has the potential to hurt the economy and consumers in the long run," said Representative David Cicilline, a Rhode Island Democrat who is the ranking member of the subcommittee that oversees antitrust matters. He raised concerns over Amazon's $13.4 billion purchase of Whole Foods over the summer, noting that antitrust laws may need an update to account for the power internet companies have over the economy.

Amazon, which declined to comment for this article, has said that its online retail business makes up a minority of all commerce and that it is producing tens of thousands of jobs in regions that have long been in decline. The company had 180,000 full-time employees in the United States at the end of 2016, nearly double its head count five years earlier. The company has said those gains help make up for the job losses from struggling brick-and-mortar retailers.

In the span of a few weeks this summer, Linda McMahon, head of the Small Business Administration, visited Amazon's headquarters in Seattle, where the company had small retailers on hand to talk about how Amazon had helped their businesses. Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, attended the opening of a new fulfillment center in Edwardsville, Ill. And Senator Rob Portman, a Republican, visited a new fulfillment center in his home state of Ohio.

"Got to meet some of the 3,000+ Ohioans employed at this plant. #Jobs," Mr. Portman wrote on Twitter at the time.

"They are doing all this reputation stuff around how it is creating jobs and that's helped it generate a lot of media attention," said Stacy Mitchell, co-director of Institute for Local Self Reliance, a nonprofit group that promotes community economic development. Last year, her organization published a paper that argued the company was making it harder for smaller retailers to make money from selling on Amazon.

Amazon has also decided in recent years to spend more money in the broader influence ecosystem of Washington. In 2016, Amazon gave more than $10,000 each to 66 think tanks, lobbying groups and political organizations. More than a dozen organizations were new to its sponsorship roster, like the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Foundation and the conservative Law & Economic Center at George Mason University.

Financing Washington's ecosystem of research and lobbying groups is a common practice for tech companies such as Google and Microsoft, but Amazon had not been as active until recent years. Last month, it donated $50 million to a White House plan to promote computer science in classrooms.

Amazon is racing to catch up. Yet even with similar lobbying armies, Google and Facebook have not escaped criticism - in their cases over their platforms' potential to shape public opinion.

"With Amazon, we need more transparency and need to look at longer term factors when it comes to competition," Amy Klobuchar, a Democratic Senator from Minnesota said in a recent interview. "The people at the Justice Department in antitrust need to look at deals in other ways."

The efforts may not directly apply to an imminent bill or regulation, but they allow the company to steer policy conversations that may be important to Amazon in the future. Amazon is hosting events for lawmakers, like the day of events in July, and holding discussions on transportation and labor policies for congressional staff and policy makers at its sleek offices near Capitol Hill. Speaker Paul D. Ryan and other political leaders have visited Amazon’s fulfillment centers in their home districts, where Amazon talks up the thousands of jobs those warehouses support.

Amazon’s strategic shift has happened as politicians are getting bolder in their criticism about the size and influence of big tech companies. Republicans and Democrats alike have focused on issues including antitrust, privacy and public disclosure.

Many of the harshest attacks have been directed at Facebook and Google, which also have robust lobbying arms in Washington. But Amazon has attracted its own set of vocal critics, who say the company’s push into groceries, fashion, transportation and other industries threatens competition. President Trump has lashed out at the company and Jeff Bezos, the company’s chief executive, multiple times, accusing the company of avoiding taxes among other things. The company has said it follows all tax laws and has supported a bill that would force online commerce sites to collect sales taxes.

“The concentration of power in the hands of a few companies has the potential to hurt the economy and consumers in the long run,” said Representative David Cicilline, a Rhode Island Democrat who is the ranking member of the subcommittee that oversees antitrust matters. He raised concerns over Amazon’s $13.4 billion purchase of Whole Foods over the summer, noting that antitrust laws may need an update to account for the power internet companies have over the economy.

Amazon, which declined to comment for this article, has said that its online retail business makes up a minority of all commerce and that it is producing tens of thousands of jobs in regions that have long been in decline. The company had 180,000 full-time employees in the United States at the end of 2016, nearly double its head count five years earlier. The company has said those gains help make up for the job losses from struggling brick-and-mortar retailers.

In the span of a few weeks this summer, Linda McMahon, head of the Small Business Administration, visited Amazon’s headquarters in Seattle, where the company had small retailers on hand to talk about how Amazon had helped their businesses. Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois,   attended the opening of a new fulfillment center in Edwardsville, Ill. And Senator Rob Portman, a Republican, visited a new fulfillment center in his home state of Ohio.

“Got to meet some of the 3,000+ Ohioans employed at this plant. #Jobs,” Mr. Portman wrote on Twitter at the time.

“They are doing all this reputation stuff around how it is creating jobs and that’s helped it generate a lot of media attention,” said Stacy Mitchell, co-director of Institute for Local Self Reliance, a nonprofit group that promotes community economic development. Last year, her organization published a paper that argued the company was making it harder for smaller retailers to make money from selling on Amazon.

Amazon has also decided in recent years to spend more money in the broader influence ecosystem of Washington. In 2016, Amazon gave more than $10,000 each to 66 think tanks, lobbying groups and political organizations. More than a dozen organizations were new to its sponsorship roster, like the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Foundation and the conservative Law & Economic Center at George Mason University.

Financing Washington’s ecosystem of research and lobbying groups is a common practice for tech companies such as Google and Microsoft, but Amazon had not been as active until recent years. Last month, it donated $50 million to a White House plan to promote computer science in classrooms.

Amazon is racing to catch up. Yet even with similar lobbying armies, Google and Facebook have not escaped criticism — in their cases over their platforms’ potential to shape public opinion.

“With Amazon, we need more transparency and need to look at longer term factors when it comes to competition,” Amy Klobuchar, a Democratic Senator from Minnesota said in a recent interview. “The people at the Justice Department in antitrust need to look at deals in other ways.”

urn:contentItem:604R-GK01-DXH2-61G8-00000-00Amazon under pressure; More protests over the weekend in Seattle; The morning buzz; New Concerns Over The Spike Of The Coronavirus; Mortgage Rates Drop To A Record Low; New Reports Reveal Public Health Officials Fail To Alert Passengers And Crew Members Who Had Flown With COVID Positive Travelers2020-06-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:06ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTJohn Meyer; Mitch Roschelle; Siraj Hashmi; Lee Carter, Sam Stovall, Paul HowardNEWSFinancial061501cb.231Amazon under pressure; More protests over the weekend in Seattle; The morning buzz; New Concerns Over The Spike Of The Coronavirus; Mortgage Rates Drop To A Record Low; New Reports Reveal Public Health Officials Fail To Alert Passengers And Crew Members Who Had Flown With COVID Positive TravelersDagen McDowell; Cheryl Casone

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning everyone, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, June 15, your top stories at 6:00 am Eastern.

Concerns over a spike in coronavirus cases sparking a global sell-off. The Dow, Nasdaq, S&P 500 snapping their three week winning streak last week and you can take a look at how the market's performed. The Dow hardest hit, down 5.5 percent.

Coronavirus cases on the rise, Texas and Florida among states seeing an increase in cases and hospitalizations. Coming up, a look at the places that pose the greatest risks for contracting coronavirus, from amusement parks to tennis courts to grocery stores.

Unrest in Atlanta, protests following the killing of a black man Friday night by police, the shooting now ruled a homicide.

Parts of Seattle remain under siege. The mayor supporting protesters, calling their actions and act of patriotism.

President Trump saying that the mayor and governor should be ashamed of themselves, tweeting that the matter can easily be fixed.

Mortgage rates dropping to a record low. Quicken Loans CEO Jay Farner joins me at 8:30 am Eastern time. Find out who can take advantages of these low rates and what it could mean for a housing recovery.

Mornings with Maria is live right now.

Fears of a second wave of coronavirus cases hitting global markets. In Europe markets are selling off down to the tune of about one percent in England, France and Germany. Restrictions easing up in the U.K. as retailers reopen, many European countries opening their borders to travelers today.

In Asia overnight you take a look at the major markets there, lower across the board from South Korea, Hong Kong, Japan and Shanghai. Beijing reimposing lock downs after a spike in coronavirus cases.

Meantime, more signs of a slow recovery in China. Industrial output coming in below expectations, rising 4.4 percent in May, retail sales declining 2.8 percent.

Oil sliding rising coronavirus cases fueling concerns over demand as maybe people don't hit the roads as expected. We have a loss about $0.59 a barrel on crude.

Cheryl Casone with some of the top stories that we're watching this morning. Good morning Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning Dagen. And a dozen states are easing more coronavirus restrictions, that's going to be happening today. But concerns are growing over a possible resurgence, as several states are seeing an uptick in cases, including Texas, which just marked its third straight day of record COVID-19 hospitalizations.

And new cases in Florida topping 2,000 for the second day in a row.

Well, the deadly shooting of a black man in Atlanta sparking a new wave of protests. Rayshard Brooks was shot and killed by a police at a Wendy's restaurant on Friday. His death ruled a homicide after an autopsy showed that he suffered two gun shot wounds to the back.

Police now have released body cam footage of that incident.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think you've had too much to drink to be driving, so put your hands behind your back for me. Here, put your hands behind your back.

You're going to get tased. You're going to get tased.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Stop.

(CROSSTALK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Come on man.

(YELLING)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: A sixty-three (ph).

(YELLING)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DAGEN: Both was terminated immediately and fellow officer Devin Brosnan has been placed on administrative duty. Rolfe could face murder charges over the incident. The shooting touched off protest all weekend, including the blocking off of interstates and they set fire to the Wendy's restaurant where Brooks was shot. There was so many people in the streets that firefighters were unable to even reach that Wendy's building to save it.

Well, police reform is going to take center state in Washington this week. Senate Republicans expected to formally role out their plan on Wednesday. House Democrats last week unveiled a sweeping plan to reform the criminal justice system.

Many leading Democrats pushing back against the calls to defund police departments all together. President Trump is expected to address police reform with an executive order.

Well, you make want to take a look inside your refrigerator, nearly 43,000 pounds of ground beef being recalled for possible E. coli contamination. The Department of Agriculture says the beef, which was purchased -- produced, excuse me, on June 1, was sold under the brand names Thomas Farms and Marketside Butcher. So far no reports of anyone becoming sick.

And those, Dagen, are your headlines from the newsroom. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much Cheryl, we'll see you shortly.

Dow Futures taking a major hit this morning, we have a 446 point loss on the blue-chips at the moment, with fears growing over a coronavirus resurgence and the potential for shutdown measures going back into place.

Joining the conversation is CFRA Chief Investment Strategist Sam Stovall, along all morning. Maslansky and Partners President Lee Carter, good morning Lee. PWC Partner Mitch Rochelle and Washington Examiner Commentary Writer and Editor Siraj Hashmi.

Welcome one and all.

Sam, what do you make of these markets here after last weeks sell-off?

SAM STOVALL, CFRA CHIEF INVESTMENT STRATEGIST: Good morning Dagen. Good morning everybody. My belief is that he market was looking for a reason to consolidate a lot of the recent gains and it found three. Last week on Tuesday we had the announcement by the National Bureau of Economic Research that we have fallen into recession and history tells us that 90 days after that announcement the market has been negative four of five times.

We also had the FOMC report its findings, basically implying that interest rates will remain low until 2022, causing some investors to think, gee, maybe they know something we don't and that things are worse than expected.

And then lastly, as you just mentioned, the increased likelihood of COVID cases sweeping the country as reopen, which could therefore put the V- shaped economic recovery into question.

MCDOWELL: Mitch Rochelle, get in here, but I -- Jay Powell of the Federal Reserve said something last week that I literally have been saying for months and it could be years before we get back to people finding jobs. It's the issue of permanent job destruction that people won't come back. Is that fully factored into the market or do you think markets overreacted to what Powell said last week?

MITCH ROCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: No, I think that that's exactly the point, Dagen. I -- you know, the V versus U shaped recovery probably isn't the debate when you look at all the data, I think on paper it's going to look like a V. The question is, is the second leg of the V as tall as the one on the way down. And do we get to the point where our economy is the same size as it was before?

I think that's the real challenge. And my question to Sam around that is, what's baked into the market in terms of the expansion of the economy? Is it, you know, factoring in the reality that we may not get back to where we were for quite some time?

MCDOWELL: Sam?

STOVALL: Well Dagen and Mitch, I think basically we have to wait and see what the second quarter GDP numbers look like. Our expectation is for a 30 -- 32 percent decline in the second quarter following a 5 percent decline in the first quarter, but then we start to see what is the likelihood for an advance.

Right now we're forecasting a 24 percent gain in the third quarter followed by a more than 9 percent advance in the fourth quarter. So, really I think we are trying to figure out exactly what happens even before the bad quarter gets reported.

MCDOWELL: Maria spoke with National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow about the recovery yesterday on "Sunday Morning Futures." Kudlow striking an optimistic tone. Sam, listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: We've got Jay Powell saying we're going to keep interest rates where they are, near zero, until 2023, as the road to recovery is long. Do you think it's going to be even worse with what we're seeing in the country today, all of this protesting and rioting?

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: I think with the rescue package and the reopening of the economy as we transition, 80 percent of small businesses, according the Chamber of Commerce, are reopening.

Business applications, new business applications are roaring, tremendous demand for housing homes, that's new homes. I think we're off to the races in what will be a very strong V-shaped recovery.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Sam, Kudlow also urging replacing that extra unemployment benefit boost, that $600 a week with a return-to-work bonus. Again, there is that compulsion to spend more money to do something to help the economy rather than just letting these businesses reopen.

STOVALL: Well, I think that the -- there is the encouragement. By keeping interest rates low that would make for business loans to be more easily applied for and received. It would also help to pay down the debt that's being incurred.

Because of this now the debt represents close to 130 percent of U.S. GDP, basically looking back to what happened right after World War II.

So, I think that there is the need for encouragement for people to go back to work, not to be paid too much to want to just stay at home.

But I think, again, expectations are that we will be seeing a V-shaped recovery, and we're looking for, as I mentioned, about 24 percent gain in Q3, and we're -- so right now I believe that the market sell-off is a natural correction, every bull market since World War II has seen one that has averaged about 10.3 percent. So, I think we have to go down to around the 2850 level before we can decide whether this correction has run its course.

MCDOWELL: When would -- do investors start worrying about the presidential election? Is that -- are people concerned about that? Because we talk about what 130 percent -- the debt is 130 percent of GDP, how are we going help pay that down, higher taxes?

STOVALL: Well, that's one of the alternatives. Certainly, keeping interest rates low so that the economy is revived and that increase in tax revenues and so forth would help pay down the debt.

Inflation is another technique that has been used in the past, but that tended to fail after the Vietnam War in the 1970s. So yes, I think now little by little investors are focusing on the upcoming election.

Traditionally it is the three month period just prior to the election where the market's direction gives investors an idea as to which party will end up getting elected. So, a downward move in the market from July 31 through October 31 would signal a replacement of the administration.

MCDOWELL: Sam, good to see you as always. Thank you so much. Sam Stovall joining us. We're just getting started this morning. Coming up next I'm going to speak with the District Attorney of Fulton County, Georgia, Paul Howard. After a weekend of unrest in Atlanta, amid that fatal shooting of Rayshard Brooks by a police officer.

At 7:00 o'clock Texas Congressman Chip Roy is here, as Texas records its highest number of COVID-19 hospitalizations since the outbreak began in March.

Then in the 8:00 o'clock hour, a former CKE Restaurant CEO Randy Posner gives us his outlook for the economic recovery.

The CEO of Quicken Loans Jay Farner weights in with tips to refinance your mortgage as mortgage rates hit now record lows.

And Indeed Chief Economist Jed Kolko tells us where to expect the next jobs in America post pandemic.

Coming up, the unmasking of General Michael Flynn insight from one former intelligence who tells Maria Bartiromo, moves by the Obama Administration were highly inappropriate.

Plus, keeping big tech in check, Amazon now under the microscope in two separate states as its business practices come into question. We've got the details.

MCDOWELL: Unrest in Atlanta, after the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man by a police officer, Rayshard Brooks was killed by police in a Wendy's parking lot after reportedly falling asleep in his car.

A scuffle broke out after he failed a sobriety test. Brook's death ruled a homicide. One officer fired and could face murder charges.

Joining me now Fulton Country District Attorney Paul Howard. District Attorney, thank you so much for being here this morning.

PAUL HOWARD, FULTON COUNTRY DISTRICT ATTORNEY: My pleasure.

MCDOWELL: Will you bring charges -- will you bring charges against the -- the fired officer, Garrett Rolfe, with 100 percent certainty? And when, this week, will you announce that?

HOWARD: Well, what we're doing now is we are examining all of the evidence and circumstances in the case and what we've planned to do is to make a decision and make that announcement then as we've indicated probably on Wednesday.

There are some technical things that we must make sure that they are done prior to the announcement. One of those things is to confirm the ballistics. We have to make sure that the guns that were retrieved from the incident, that they're actually matched to the projectiles in the body of Mr. Brooks.

But, we are hopeful that we can make this announcement probably some time around Wednesday.

MCDOWELL: What charges are you expecting to bring? Can you give us insight into that?

HOWARD: Well, right now under Georgia law we are looking at three possible charges, first charge being murder. Murder is a -- a charge that carries a life sentence, up to death and it is the -- essentially around and intentional killing.

The second charge that we're looking at is the charge of felony murder. Felony murder involves a death that occurs as a result of the commission of an underlying felony. And in this case the underlying felony would be aggravated assault.

The third charge that we are considering as we consider the facts would be voluntary manslaughter.

MCDOWELL: Are you considering charges or are you at least weighing charges against the second officer who's been put on leave, Devin Brosnan, is that something you're looking at?

HOWARD: Yes, we're looking at the conduct of both officers in this circumstance and when we reach our conclusions, as I've indicated on Wednesday, we will reach conclusions regarding both officers.

MCDOWELL: The fact that a taser was taken away from one of the officers, did that -- because I know, and this is laid out in the "New York Times" today, that officers, broadly speaking, are trained that they have the right to escalate their use of force if they believe someone is threatening to incapacitate them. How does the taser play into your decision making on charges?

HOWARD: Well, the taser is something that happened in this case and it is certainly one of the factors that we have to consider, but what we are focused upon is the moment of the shooting. He was shot twice and we're looking at those circumstances that occurred at that moment.

What the law says is, at the time that that shot was fired what we have to determine, based upon the perceptions of a reasonable officer is whether or not the, Mr. Brooks, at that time posed a serious threat of bodily harm or death to that officer or someone else. And so that's what we're doing, we are focused upon that moment to see whether or not the facts indicate whether or not that occurred.

MCDOWELL: Before we go District Attorney, in terms of the arson and the burning of the Wendy's restaurant, any leads in that? Will you fully -- if you have a suspect eventually in custody will you prosecute that case?

HOWARD: Yes, we -- we would. There is an investigation that is occurring right now and as of this moment I believe also there's information that's been put out on the media of some possible person who might have been involved. But when that person or persons is apprehended we certainly would prosecute them in our office.

MCDOWELL: District Attorney Paul Howard. District Attorney, thank you so much for being here. Please come back. Please keep us up to date on what happens --

HOWARD: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: -- in the death of Rayshard Brooks.

Coming up, the unmasking of General Michael Flynn, insight from one former intelligence official telling Maria Bartiromo that moves by the Obama Administration were highly inappropriate.

Plus, getting back to work, the Chief Economist for job search engine Indeed tells us where to look for America's up and coming jobs post pandemic. Stay with us.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. The unmasking of General Michael Flynn, former Acting Director of National Intelligence Richard Granell on "Sunday Morning Future's" yesterday, calling moves by the Obama Administration highly inappropriate.

Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We had Ron Johnson on the other day, a couple of weeks ago, here on this program and his investigation is centering on the transition of power from the Obama Administration to the Trump Administration and during that transition when Trump was fully in place there were 125 leaks during the first 126 days of the Administration.

RICHARD GRANELL, FORMER ACTING DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL INTELLIGENCE: I think that transition period is key and it's why -- once Donald Trump won the election in 2016, all the way through to Inauguration Day, that period of time is when we know who is coming into the White House, we know the team like -- like General Flynn and his team and President Trump, that's when we're supposed to have the Obama Administration or the current administration begin to hand off and have a transition time.

That's we have an election in November and an Inauguration in January, is for a peaceful transition of power. That was blown by the Obama Administration and I just don't think that unmasking during the transition period is appropriate, especially at the levels that they did.

And we even had Joe Biden, the Vice President of the United States at the time, unmasking in -- in this transition period, and I believe it was in January when they literally were on the down slope to Trump's inauguration. This is inappropriate. I think you can make the argument for unmasking at other times, but -- but to unmask during this transition period, to me, is another level --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: This as efforts by Flynn to have his criminal charges dismissed, that goes on. Siraj, we learned last week that Lindsey Graham was granted sweeping subpoena power by the Senate Judiciary Committee. How high will he go? What do you make of all of this?

SIRAJ HASHMI, WASHINGTON EXAMINER COMMENTARY WRITER AND EDITOR: Well, as Attorney General Barr indicated that he won't open the criminal investigation into former President Barack Obama or former Vice President Joe Biden, so it could go as high up as say maybe the Attorney General Eric Holder or Loretta Lynch.

I -- I would -- I would say more Loretta Lynch because Attorney -- Eric Holder wasn't at -- in -- in office at that time. But, I will say, a couple takeaways from acting DNI's Rick Granell's interview, was that one, the over-classification of the Michael Flynn investigation sort of shows you or indicates that there may have been a cover-up within the intelligence community.

And I think the next step here by John Ratcliffe, who is now the DNI, has to find out who ordered these over-classifications and also the inappropriateness of the timing of the unmasking during the transition period sort of shows you that the Obama Administration was almost trying to sew seeds of disruption that will continue to undermine the Trump presidency and were -- and his presidency as of now is currently still recovering from that disruption.

MCDOWELL: Lee, do the American people and voters understand the seriousness of this, because a lot of has happened obviously in the three and half years since this unmasking, and particularly in the middle of this pandemic and dramatic economic downturn. What do voters think of this?

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT OF MASLANSKY & PARTNERS: I don't think this is on the top of voter's radars. Sadly there's so much news, there's so much that's going on that impacts individual's pocketbooks and livelihoods, when you've got 6 out of 10 Americans saying that they don't think that they're going to be able to make their bills this month because of the economy, because of what's going on right now related to COVID, this is not top of mind.

What I do know is that this an issue that's going along partisan lines. If you're a Trump supporter you are outraged at the unmasking. If you are a Democrat and you are a Biden supporter or if you are just opposed to Trump in general, this is something that has you outraged when you learn about it -- not outraged, (inaudible) they'll explain (ph) it away (ph).

And so, very, very much on party lines. I don't think this is going to have a huge impact unless and until the Trump Administration can tell us right away that's going to make it resonate with the American people. Right now, I think it's just a lot of a wall covering frankly.

MCDOWELL: Thank you all. Coming up, fear of flying, new reports reveal public health officials fail to alert passengers and crew members who had flown with COVID positive travelers.

Plus, Americans eager to ease back into normalcy, but are common public areas still unsafe. We'll tell which places posed the greatest risk for contracting coronavirus.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, June 15th. Your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern.

Concerns over a spike in coronavirus cases sparking a global selloff. Futures sharply lower, but well off their lows of the morning. A 568 point loss on the blue chips at the moment.

Taking on global market action in Europe it is the same scene, red across the board. Losses of one percent or more in England, France and Germany. Restrictions are easing up in the UK as retailers reopen. Many European countries opening their boarders to travelers today.

In Asia overnight it was a selloff in all four major markets there. Beijing re-imposing lockdowns after a spike in coronavirus cases. Meantime, more signs of a slow recovery in China. Industrial output coming in below expectations, up 4.4 percent in May. Retail sales declining 2.8 percent.

Oil, in the meantime, sliding, as rising coronavirus cases fuel concerns over demand. The cost of crude down more than two percent.

A US fighter jet reportedly crashes in England. Cheryl Casone has the details. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Yeah, Dagen, here's what we know right now. British media outlets are reporting that the F-15 fighter jet crashed into the North Sea, this would be of the Northern coast of England. It happened earlier this morning. We're hearing the jet was taking part in a formation drill at the time, and the pilot was the only person on board. Rescue crews have arrived. We're going to keep monitoring any reports we get on that search coming out of England.

Back here at home, gas prices are marching higher for the sixth straight week according the AAA. National average is $2.10 a gallon, but that is still down $.70 from a year ago, and just slightly up from the low of $1.74 in April, as states began to ease travel restrictions. Analysts expect gas prices to move higher as the summer driving season heats up.

Well, today major league baseball owners are expected to announce what is next for the 2020 season, what's left of it anyway. The players union ending negotiations over the weekend, and now they are reportedly demanding the league just set the schedule and tell them when to show up. The union rejected the latest offer of a 72 game season, and players receiving 70 percent prorated pay.

And finally, here's a look at what is trending this morning on foxbusiness.com. Walmart tests self checkout only location, and its being tested in Fayetteville, Arkansas. It could go national if it works out. Slack to offer permanent work from home to most employees. The company extending its work from home policy indefinitely beyond September 1. And this one, tourists dip their toes in water as top Mexican beach getaways reopen. As of now, hotels can allow guests into the water, but at least in Mexico the public beaches do remain closed, Dagen. And those are a lot of your headlines this morning. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl. Amazon under pressure. State investigators from California and Washington state reportedly looking into the tech giant's business practices, particularly how the company treats third party sellers and its online marketplace. Joining me now, Tech Analyst, Managing Partner at Starship Capital, John Meyer. John, good of you to be here. What are they looking at, and how big of a risk is this to Amazon's business model?

JOHN MEYER, MANAGING PARTNER, STARSHIP CAPITAL: So, what is being looked at right now is the dynamic between Amazon and external sellers. So, that let's say is mom and pop shop selling their product on Amazon and how Amazon is able to use data on, the purchase data, the amount of money going into sales and marketing, to actually create competing products with Amazon's own third party vendors. And the reason this is so key is that, due to the fact that Amazon has so much data on both what consumers are buying as well as how third party vendors are selling it, it's leading to the conclusion that it's a handful of very unfair business practices, as it relates to these third party vendors.

MCDOWELL: Mitch, is this just a sliver of the regulatory risk that Amazon is facing? Particularly given how much more powerful this behemoth has gotten during the pandemic, the coronavirus shutdowns.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER AND BUSINESS DEVELOPER, PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS: I think the fact that we're all stuck at home, and we're Googling, and shopping has a lot to do with it. But if you look back in history and big conglomerates that have been created, that have been ultimately broken up by government, look at the breakup of AT&T, as an example, so my question is, to John, what are the, who are their principal competitors out there? Obviously smaller in scale, that would benefit from a breakup, or has Amazon just monopolized the market? Do the mom and pops have an opportunity at an eBay or an Etsy to compete? Or is all of the big data that Amazon have make it impossible for them to compete outside of Amazon?

MEYER: Yeah, I think right now Amazon simply has too much data on its consumers and its vendors and, honestly needs to be broken up. Right now, as a small business, there aren't many other places you can go to reach as many eyeballs as Amazon. And the problem is Amazon reels you in with the idea that data will help you as a third party vendor, but now what's happening is Amazon is trying to create their own brand within their own store, to then compete with the mom and pop shop. So, I think that is where this begins to get quite dangerous small to medium sized businesses where Amazon is using again, their own platform to sell their own, you know, third party branded products to compete with everyone trying to sell on the platform itself.

MCDOWELL: And I believe that regulators in Europe are bringing charges related to this very third party seller issue. Meantime, the House Judiciary Committee wants the heads of Apple, Facebook, Amazon and the Alphabet to testify as part of the committee's Tech Competition Investigation. This, amid growing scrutiny over the power of technology platforms. John, your take.

MEYER: Well, I think at this point, you know, companies like Google and Apple simply need to be broken up. I think if you put Amazon in there as well, company like Facebook where they're dominating based again on data, and as we get into the next few years, technologies like artificial intelligence and machine learning are getting more and more powerful, these are technologies that are going to make these companies even more monopolistic. And so, I think I've consistently said that government lags behind, you know, three to five years, always in terms of regulation as it relates to possible monopolistic practices. So, I think it's a great next step.

MCDOWELL: Wait, you just said that you think that Google and Apple need to be broken up. That was kind of a throw away comment, and you, it came across like that's kind of a foregone conclusion. I know a lot of people who might disagree with you on that.

MEYER: Yeah, well, you know, if you look at the size of these companies, and their scale and reach at this point, it's orders of magnitude launch are beyond anything we've seen before. And, you know, the problem with a company like Google, who I put in that list, is again, that they literally own the entire, you know, online search business. If you look at them and Facebook combined, you don't have anywhere else to go. And I think the size of these businesses is again, to the point where you cannot compete as an upstart player. There's a reason why there hasn't been a competitor to Google in over a decade. Or a competitor to Facebook in over a decade.

MCDOWELL: Before we go, Siraj, if you look at Washington and if you have maybe if the Democrats take the Senate, these technology companies are, broadly speaking, in terms of their employees, very progressive. They're big donors to Democratic causes and candidates. Is that something that, are Democrats more likely, would a Democrat in the White House more likely crack down on these companies or not? Do they think that they would get a free pass if they Democrats are fully in power in D.C.?

SIRAJ HASHMI, COMMENTARY WRITER AND EDITOR, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: That's a very good question, because it depends on which Democrats end up filling a potential Biden administration. If you have say, Elizabeth Warren, at say the helm of say the, I wouldn't say the Justice Department, but having a significant position in the Cabinet, then you could see actually a big break up of a lot of these tech companies, because she has probably been one of the leading voices, along with Senator Bernie Sanders. And, sort of at least invigorating and energizing the progressive base to get tough on Amazon. And you hear, obviously, AOC in the last year, sort of taking a victory lap when Amazon abandoned its plans to build its second headquarters in New York City. So, its definitely a good possibility that Democrats will not show any favor to these tech companies, as much as Republicans.

MCDOWELL: And, Elon Musk's no fan of Amazon. It's when Amazon censored Alex Berenson's book on the coronavirus and wouldn't publish it. Elon Musk, he just tweets, break them up, monopoly, and boom that book magically appears on Kindle. John Meyer, it was great to see you. Thank you so much.

MEYER: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, we're seeing a sharp selloff at the open. Futures taking a hit amid growing fears of a coronavirus resurgence in a potential lockdown. Hear about Governor Cuomo's latest threats. Plus, swapping statues, protestors calling to replace Confederate monuments in some Southern states with modern day role models. We'll tell you who.

MCDOWELL: More protests over the weekend in Seattle. Demonstrators sealing off a six block radius in the Capitol Hill neighborhood dubbed the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone. Mayor Jenny Durkan saying she does not know when police will reenter the area and says that the city could be seeing a summer of love. President Trump weighing in the situation, tweeting this, does anyone notice how little the radical left takeover of Seattle is being discusses in the fake news media? That is very much on purpose, because they know how badly this weakness and ineptitude play politically. The Mayor and Governor should be ashamed of themselves. Easily fixed. Exclamation point. Joining me now, Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. We've talked about this in relation to, say, Minneapolis, Judge, or any you know, kind of disbanding of police departments. It's the tenth amendment, not only, right of the state, but obligation of the state, to basically, provide law and order, right?

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Yes. And, good morning Dagen. The tenth amendment, which reserves to the states the power, the police power, also obliges them to exercise the police power, and provide basic safety. So, look, the Mayor says this is a carnival like atmosphere, and she want to play it out using a very soft touch. It's probably not a carnival like atmosphere if you live there. If you need to drive there. If you need to shop there, and if you need to use the public street and the public sidewalks that the government owns, which have been taken over by these people.

I agree with the President that its crazy, and the people have a right to live there. On the other hand, the Federal government does not have the right to come in unless, are you ready for this, the legislature of the state of Washington or if the legislature can't meet, because this thing is surrounding the Capitol Building, then the Governor of the state of Washington. So, right now it looks like its going to be a standoff. If you live there your property values are down. You can barely get in and out of your home.

MCDOWELL: It's just astonishing that this is going on and, by the way, the summer of love? Well, the summer of love gave way to like assaults and drug overdoses, and quite frankly it is that idiocy that has reason that San Francisco is the way it is now. Is that they think that they, it harkens back to some fable, some fallacy left over from what, 51 years ago. I digress, because there's another, well, fiery garbage pit. We'll talk about New York, Governor Andrew Cuomo threatening to reverse the reopening process after photos of crowds ignoring social distancing guidelines in New York City and the Hamptons surfaced over the weekend. Judge Napolitano, you know what, because the city is closed, people are crowding into smaller areas. If they would open up more spaces, if they would open up the restaurants in a small way, open up the bars in a small way, you wouldn't have this clustering effect. What do you make of this?

NAPOLITANO: I could not agree with you more. I mean, the Governor, is showing a dictatorial side to him, too many of you, too close together, and too small a space, I'm now going to punish you for it. That's not what elect Governor's for. Where was he when thousands of people were marching in the street over the death of George Floyd and then it manifested itself into anger about police, and then anger about government in general? So, he wasn't threatening to shut down the city then. But now he's threatening to shut down the city because a bunch of kids sat a little too close to each other at a table at a restaurant, which blocked its name from public view on West Broadway. Why doesn't he just let people do what they want to do and take the chances that they want to take. Enough is enough, Governor Cuomo.

MCDOWELL: Yes, and I'm still waiting for him to take ownership for that order sent to the nursing homes in late March of this year forcing them to take COVID positive patients back into nursing homes without, and it forbid them from testing those patients. I think that order was in place six weeks. Thousands died because of it. Ultimately that is on his shoulders. I digress. Judge Napolitano, it is great to see you.

NAPOLITANO: Don't hold your breath waiting for him to take responsibility for that.

MCDOWELL: I won't. Although I am blue in the face, because of Governor Cuomo. We'll be right back.

MCDOWELL: Time for the morning buzz. First up, replacing Confederate monuments with celebrities. Black Lives Matter protests across the country renewing calls to remove statues and monuments from the Confederacy. Some local communities looking to replace them with modern day role models. Nashville considering honoring Dolly Parton. New Orleans could pay tribute to Britney Spears. Siraj.

HASHMI: I mean, Britney Spears might be a bridge too far, but I could get behind Dolly Parton. But I mean we live in a society where there's a lot of history revisionism. People don't understand their history. I mean, look at how these Confederate statues sort of, they are a symbol, obviously, you know, America was founded on rebellion, and when you have the Confederacy sort of waging rebellion to preserve the institution of slavery, keeping those statues in place is sort of a reward to the states that fought for the Confederacy to preserve slavery. I think, obviously, tearing them down isn't going to solve the issue, because all you're going to do is create more division. But if you take them down and put them in a museum so people can actually learn and understand our history.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

HASHMI: That is something that is probably better, and it will encourage in people to actually learn about our history to understand how these figures actually tried to preserve something that is absolutely abhorrent. I will say one more thing and that is if we actually understood some of the statues that are being defaced, some of them are actually of known abolitionists.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HASHMI: An effect that a lot of people are, say members of Black Lives Matter or Antifa, are defacing them, it says a lot about how much history is being taught in our country.

MCDOWELL: Indeed. Dolly Parton's the Queen of America, and there should be statues in every town square of Dolly. Moving on to Berlin, the nightclub industry gone for good. The club capital of the world is worried that tourists may not return because of social distancing. Club goers making up nearly a quarter of Berlin tourist every year, bringing in significant revenue. Lee, people who've never been to Berlin, maybe don't understand what some of the clubs involve, but it's a lot of close contact shall we say.

LEE CARTER, PARTNERS PRESIDENT, POLLSTER AND MASLANSKY: Oh, my goodness. I mean, yeah. It is a party city and people are close, and they are sweating. So, it's a big problem for them. And they're going to have to figure out how they're going to survive through this. Some of their live streaming events, I think, are popular, but are they going to be able to make them through it? I don't know. It's a big deal for Berlin.

MCDOWELL: It is. More Mornings with Maria before I say something I'll regret, after the break.
